Layering.text: In this PDF painting guide I’ll be painting Cable from Atomic Mass Games’ Marvel: Crisis Protocol Miniatures Game.
And I’ve chosen to prime the cloak (and head) separately from the body:
I then lightened this up with the addition of some Tenere Yellow and some White, and applied some highlights from above:
I’ve also chosen to save time by using the airbrush to colour the cloak; this is just a couple of thin layers of Gobi Brown over some zenithal highlights:
For the skin I’m using a mix of Basic Flesh and African Shadow:
(I initially applied a single, semi-transparent layer of this but later went for a more opaque finish.)
For the hair I’m going to block the main tones in using a blue-ish grey scale made of Anthracite Gray, Graphite, and White Sands:
I’m now painting the eyes with some Deck Tan:
I’ve now painted the skin:
A single layer of this allows some natural shading to occur:
I’ve now chosen to glue on the cloak and the head:
I’m now adding some of the more greenish Caribbean Blue to add my brighter highlights:
I’m now highlighting all of the yellow areas by adding increasing amounts of Sahara Yellow to the base tone:
After reaching pure Sahara Yellow I’m adding some Tenere Yellow for the brighter highlights:
I’m now going to add some NMM-style highlights to the left arm, initially using a blueish grey scale by adding Titanium White and maybe some Ivory into the Black and Dark Sea Blue base tone:
I might also mix a little of the dark blue suit tone into some of the shadows:
I’ve also added a little White for my brightest highlights:
And I’m now lightening this with Tenere Yellow for the brighter highlights:
I’m now pushing the skin tone highlights a little further...
I’m then mixing a dark black-brown tone and drawing inside the patches of Ivory:
To help me get a sense of how the whole figure is looking I’ve now also refined the base as described in the video series, including applying some pieces of cork rock and scatter etc:
I’ve also chosen to add some Cantabric Blue to some of the off-black sooty tones:
And I’m now painting some Fluorescent Yellow mixed with a little of the Red on top:
I’m now using some cool gray tones to paint the smoke clouds but avoiding the recesses (you can see this process more fully in the Deadpool and M.O.D.O.K.
This process can be taken as far as you like; I’ve added another layer of Seraphim Sepia followed with some final scratch

Basecoating.text: I then lightened this up with the addition of some Tenere Yellow and some White, and applied some highlights from above:
I’ve also chosen to save time by using the airbrush to colour the cloak; this is just a couple of thin layers of Gobi Brown over some zenithal highlights:
For the skin I’m using a mix of Basic Flesh and African Shadow:
(I initially applied a single, semi-transparent layer of this but later went for a more opaque finish.)
For the hair I’m going to block the main tones in using a blue-ish grey scale made of Anthracite Gray, Graphite, and White Sands:
I’ve now painted the skin:
You may of course choose to paint the shoulder pad and/or boots in a metallic grey instead...
A single layer of this allows some natural shading to occur:
I’m now going to highlight the skin, and I ended up using a mix of Beige Red with the Basic Flesh used earlier (to introcuce a bit more of a satin finish):
I’ve now chosen to glue on the cloak and the head:
I’m now adding some of the more greenish Caribbean Blue to add my brighter highlights:
I’m now highlighting all of the yellow areas by adding increasing amounts of Sahara Yellow to the base tone:
After reaching pure Sahara Yellow I’m adding some Tenere Yellow for the brighter highlights:
I’m now going to add some NMM-style highlights to the left arm, initially using a blueish grey scale by adding Titanium White and maybe some Ivory into the Black and Dark Sea Blue base tone:
I’ve also added a little White for my brightest highlights:
And I’m now lightening this with Tenere Yellow for the brighter highlights:
To achieve some more glinting highlights we can apply a few small touches of White, then brush some of the Antares Red on top:
I’m now pushing the skin tone highlights a little further...
Next I’m adding some chipped weathering to the armoured boots and shoulder pad, firstly by applying some Ivory - focusing on the edges:
I’m now adding some dark-brown weathering to the base of the cape using mainly Walnut mixed with Black:
I’ve also chosen to add some Cantabric Blue to some of the off-black sooty tones:
And I’m now painting some Fluorescent Yellow mixed with a little of the Red on top:
I’m now using some cool gray tones to paint the smoke clouds but avoiding the recesses (you can see this process more fully in the Deadpool and M.O.D.O.K.

Finishing Touches.text: I then lightened this up with the addition of some Tenere Yellow and some White, and applied some highlights from above:
(I initially applied a single, semi-transparent layer of this but later went for a more opaque finish.)
I’ve now painted the skin:
I’m now going to highlight the skin, and I ended up using a mix of Beige Red with the Basic Flesh used earlier (to introcuce a bit more of a satin finish):
I’m now adding some of the more greenish Caribbean Blue to add my brighter highlights:
I’m now highlighting all of the yellow areas by adding increasing amounts of Sahara Yellow to the base tone:
After reaching pure Sahara Yellow I’m adding some Tenere Yellow for the brighter highlights:
I’m now going to add some NMM-style highlights to the left arm, initially using a blueish grey scale by adding Titanium White and maybe some Ivory into the Black and Dark Sea Blue base tone:
I’ve also added a little White for my brightest highlights:
We can also highlight the other metallic details along the way:
I’m now adding some touches of Gobi Brown and just playing around a bit until I’m happy with the look:
I’m now hitting the remaining little metallic details:
And I’m now lightening this with Tenere Yellow for the brighter highlights:
To achieve some more glinting highlights we can apply a few small touches of White, then brush some of the Antares Red on top:
I’m now pushing the skin tone highlights a little further...
I’ve chosen to create the impression of burn marks around the holes and the ragged edges of the cape so here I’m applying some Black in varying strengths:
I’m then mixing a dark black-brown tone and drawing inside the patches of Ivory:
I’m now returning to the cape where I’m now dry brushing some dark brown around the base:
I’ve also chosen to add some Cantabric Blue to some of the off-black sooty tones:
And to create a burnt embers effect I’m now adding some small dots of pure white (a good, heavy-body white like Titanium White works well for this):
And I’m now painting some Fluorescent Yellow mixed with a little of the Red on top:

Generic Highlights.text: Firstly I’ve chosen to magnetize the telekinetic shield with a couple of 2mm-wide magnets (and corresponding magnets near the front edge of the base):
For the rifle and the remaining metallic details (including the left arm) I’m using a mix of Black and Dark Sea Blue.
We can also add some Ivory or Tenere Yellow for the brighter highlights:
Next I’m going to highlight the blue outfit firstly by progressing up to pure Caspian Blue from the base tone:
I’m now adding some of the more greenish Caribbean Blue to add my brighter highlights:

Question 1.question: How many layers should I use for highlights?
Question 1.statement: There is no exact answer to how many layers should be used for highlights based on the given sources. However, different sources suggest adding a mix of colors such as white, Ivory, or Tenere Yellow to achieve brighter highlights. Applying a few small touches of white may also result in glinting highlights. Additionally, the skin tone highlights can be pushed further with the help of colors such as Caribbean Blue or Beige Red with Basic Flesh. Furthermore, it is suggested to add a little white for the brightest highlights. Some sources also indicate using multiple layers for the highlight finish by mentioning applying a semi-transparent layer initially, followed by an opaque finish. Thus, the number of layers can vary depending on the technique and the desired result.

Question 2.question: Are washes used?
Question 2.statement: There is no information in the sources that indicates whether washes are used or not.

annotations.text: For the skin I’m using a mix of Basic Flesh and African Shadow:
I’ve now painted the skin:
And I’m brushing a mix of Fluorescent Red and Yellow over the left eye:
You may of course choose to paint the shoulder pad and/or boots in a metallic grey instead...
For the yellow parts of the outfit I’m using a mix of Iroko and Gobi Brown:
And for the brown pouches and strap on the shoulder I’ve chosen Walnut mixed with a little Black:
I’m now going to highlight the skin, and I ended up using a mix of Beige Red with the Basic Flesh used earlier (to introcuce a bit more of a satin finish):
We can also add some Ivory or Tenere Yellow for the brighter highlights:
I’m now using Deep Red to paint the two X-Force symbols on the chest and the belt:
I’m now returning to the cape where I’m now dry brushing some dark brown around the base:

Question 3.question: Any techniques to improve my own painting, based on the techniques in this document?
Question 3.statement: The sources describe various techniques used to paint a figure, including mixing colors, highlighting, and adding details. To improve your own painting skills, you could try experimenting with these techniques and adapting them to your own style. Mixing colors to create new shades, adding highlights to create depth and dimension, and incorporating small details can all enhance the overall look of a painted figure. Additionally, the sources suggest using varying strengths of paint to create different effects, which is another technique you could try. Overall, practice and experimentation will be key in improving your painting abilities.
